citeinfo.title: Beach_Nourishment

descript.abstract: Beach Nourishment projects occur throughout coastal states in the United States. These projects can be privately, federally or state funded. Material used in nourishment comes from a variety of sources (inland sources, dredged navigational channels or offshore sites). This GIS dataset combines historical data compiled in the Western Carolina University Beach Nourishment Viewer database, as well as the National Beach Nourishment Database generated by the American Shore and Beach Preservation Association. The data contain attribute information on the general location of sand placement, primary funding source and funding type, volume of sediment emplacement (in cubic yards), length of beach nourished (in feet) and cost and inflated cost for over 2,000 beach nourishment episodes dating back to 1923.
descript.purpose: To support coastal and ocean planning and other activities pursuant to the Energy Policy Act, Coastal Zone Management Act, Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act, National Environmental Policy Act, Rivers and Harbors Act and the Submerged Lands Act.

procstep.procdesc: (1) ‘Master’ Database was downloaded from Western Carolina University Program for the Study of Developed Shorelines in Excel format. (2) These data were compared with the data from the online National Beach Nourishment Database (NBND): https://gim2.aptim.com/ASBPANationwideRenourishment/ (3) 2016-2018 data that were not contained in the WCU database were collected from the NBND (4) These data were then combined into one resulting point data Excel spreadsheet and imported into ArcGIS to create the resulting database

edom.edomvd: Artificially moving sand from an updrift beach to a downdrift beach in order to bypass a natural or artificial obstruction such as an inlet or jetty.

Federal grant funds derived from federal offshore lease revenues to the oil-producing states of Alabama, Alaska, California, Louisiana, Mississippi and Texas for conservation, protection, or restoration of coastal areas.
A U.S. Army Corps of Engineers experimental effort that places sand in an offshore location, rather than directly on a beach.
An effort to reestablish or improve coastal habitat that has been degraded or damaged by natural or human activities.

Designed to create an artificial beach berm in order to provide a minimum level of protection to vulnerable coastal development, usually post-storm. All Federal nourishment episodes classified as Emergency are funded through FEMA or the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers.
Designed to construct an artificial dune in order to provide a minimum level of protection to vulnerable coastal development, usually post-storm.
Sediment (known as dredge spoil) resulting from a navigation-related dredging effort is placed on a beach rather than dumped offshore or in an upland location.
Mitigation of shoreline damages attributable to Federal navigation structures (jetties).
Nourishment episodes undertaken for the primary purpose of reducing storm-related damage to static human economic development placed behind dynamic shorelines.
